#Summary1=(human1) Using the example of Alaska's Permanent Fund and an essay by Thomas Paine, Peter Barnes argues that paying dividends to everyone from a national common wealth system based on natural resources and infrastructure such as the Internet is a promising idea to help poor and middle class families, tackle climate change, reform capitalism, and promote equal rights in America.

#Summary2=(claude-3-5-sonnet-20241022) Peter Barnes argues that implementing a nationwide system of "common wealth dividends" like Alaska's Permanent Fund could help save the middle class by providing each American with up to $5,000 annually from shared resources like carbon permits, airwaves, and financial infrastructure.

#Summary3=(gpt4o) Peter Barnes suggests adopting a common wealth dividend system similar to Alaska's model, using resources like carbon permits and public infrastructures, to provide fair income distribution and support the middle class, addressing income inequality while enhancing prosperity without heavy government intervention.

#Summary4=(Meta-Llama-3-8B-Instruct) Peter Barnes argues that a system of distributing equal dividends to everyone, funded by common resources, could help reduce poverty and income inequality in the US.

#Summary5=(Qwen2.5-7B-Instruct) To address income inequality and support the middle class, a national system similar to Alaska's Permanent Fund could distribute regular dividends to all citizens based on shared resources like natural assets and societal infrastructure, potentially providing economic stability and reducing poverty.
#Text=10 : How to Save the Middle Class When Jobs Do n’t Pay ( Barnes )
#Text=By Peter Barnes
#Text=#argument , #sharedvalues , #reportinginformation , #logos , #ethos , #pathos , #kairos , #currentevents , #causalargument , #proposal , #finances #advice
#Text=Photo by Laity Lodge Family Camp under a CC license .
#Text=There ’s long been a notion that , because money is a prerequisite for survival and security , everyone should be assured some income just for being alive .
#Text=The notion has been advanced by liberals such as James Tobin , John Kenneth Galbraith , and George McGovern , and by conservatives like Friedrich Hayek , Milton Friedman , and Richard Nixon .
#Text=It ’s embedded in the board game Monopoly , in which all players get equal payments when they pass Go .
#Text=And yet , with one exception , Americans have been unable to agree on any plan that guarantees some income to everyone .
#Text=The reasons lie mostly in the stories that surround such income .
#Text=Is it welfare ?
#Text=Is it redistribution ?
#Text=Does it require higher taxes and bigger government ?
#Text=Americans think dimly of all these things .
#Text=But then , there ’s the exception .

#Text=Jay Hammond , the Republican governor of Alaska from 1974 to 1982 , was an independent thinker who conceived of , and then persuaded Alaska ’s legislators to adopt , the world ’s first system for paying equal dividends to everyone .
#Text=In Hammond ’s model , the money comes not from taxes but from a common resource : North Slope oil .
#Text=Using proceeds from that gift of nature , the Alaska Permanent Fund has paid equal yearly dividends to every resident , including children , ranging from about $ 1,000 to over $ 3,000 .
#Text=( Bear in mind that a family of four collects four same - sized dividends . )
#Text=While this is n’t enough to live on , it nicely supplements Alaskans ’ other earnings .
#Text=And paying such dividends regularly for more than thirty years has bolstered the state ’s economy , reduced poverty , and made Alaska one of the least unequal states in America .
#Text=The question Americans in the lower 48 should now ask is : Did Alaska find the right formula ?
#Text=If it can convert part of its common wealth into equal dividends for everyone , can the rest of America do the same ? [ ... ]
#Text=How Would It Work Nationally ?
#Text=How might a common wealth dividend system work at the national level ?
#Text=The easy part is distributing the dividends .
#Text=As in Alaska , enrollment could be done online and payments could wired electronically at a cost of pennies per transaction .
#Text=The Social Security Administration could set that up in a jiffy .
#Text=The harder part is collecting the revenue .
#Text=In my latest book , With Liberty and Dividends For All , I show how , over time , we could generate enough revenue to pay dividends of up to $ 5,000 per person per year .
#Text=Initially , a sizable chunk would come from selling a declining number of permits to dump carbon into our air .
#Text=Later , more revenue could flow from our monetary infrastructure , our patent and copyright systems , and our electromagnetic airwaves .
#Text=Consider what $ 5,000 per person per year would mean .
#Text=If a child ’s dividends were saved and invested starting from birth , they ’d yield enough to pay for a debt - free college education at a public university .
#Text=In midlife , $ 5,000 per person would add 25 percent to the income of a family of four earning $ 80,000 a year .
#Text=In late life , it would boost the average retiree ’s Social Security benefit by about 30 percent .
#Text=Thus , dividends from common wealth would provide a badly - needed boost for poor and middle class families during what promises to be a lasting shortage of good - paying jobs .
#Text=Surprisingly , the core idea behind Alaska ’s dividends is over two centuries old .

#Text=In his 1796 essay “ Agrarian Justice , ” American patriot Thomas Paine distinguished between two kinds of property : “ natural property , or that which comes to us from the Creator of the universe -- such as the earth , air , water … [ and ] artificial or acquired property , the invention of men . ”
#Text=The second kind of property , Paine argued , must necessarily be distributed unequally , but the first kind belongs to everyone equally .
#Text=It is the “ legitimate birthright ” of every man and woman , “ not charity but a right . ”
#Text=And Paine went further .

#Text=He proposed a practical way to implement that right : create a “ National Fund ” to pay every man and woman a lump sum ( roughly $ 17,000 in today ’s money ) at age twenty - one , and a stipend of about $ 1,000 a month after age fiftyfive .
#Text=Revenue would come from what Paine called “ ground rent ” paid by landowners .
#Text=He even showed mathematically how this could work .
#Text=Presciently , Paine recognized that land , air , and water could be monetized not just for the benefit of a few but for the good of all .
#Text=Further , he saw that this could be done at a national level .
#Text=This was a remarkable feat of analysis and imagination , and it ’s time to apply it broadly .
#Text=Today , Paine ’s core idea — that everyone has a right to equal income from common wealth — can be applied not just to natural resources but also to the creations of society .
#Text=Consider , for example , the immense value created by our legal , intellectual , and financial infrastructures , the Internet , and our economy as a whole .
#Text=This value is n’t created by single individuals or corporations ; it ’s created collectively and hence belongs equally to all .
#Text=In a fairer economy some of it would actually be distributed to all .

#Text=The ideal mechanism for doing this would be common wealth dividends — simple , transparent , direct ( not trickle down ) , built on co-ownership rather than redistribution , and politically appealing .
#Text=And here ’s the best part .
#Text=If Paine ’s idea and Alaska ’s model were applied at sufficient scale , the implications would be vast .
#Text=The current tendencies of capitalism to widen inequality and devour nature would be self - corrected .
#Text=Instead of plutocracy and climate change , our market economy would generate widely - shared , earth - friendly prosperity .
#Text=And it would achieve these goals automatically , without much need for government intervention .
#Text=Is this wild - eyed dreaming ?
#Text=Possibly , but no more so than universal suffrage or Social Security once were .
#Text=Common wealth dividends could be the next step in America ’s long march toward equal rights — and the game - changer that leads to a new version of capitalism .
#Text=But first , we have to see the opportunity and demand it .
